large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: How Big Is an Elephant?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, dance, and introduce vocabulary (measure, how big?).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What is an example of a really big animal?
Read for enjoyment, pointing out height and length in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time; Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long”; Use formal or informal measurement tools (e.g., balance scale, cups, blocks, paper clips, etc.) to observe and describe weight, length, and volume; Measure, describe, and compare capacity or how much can be placed inside an object using like units and words like “empty” and “full”; Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.”

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review measurement and the concepts of how many and how big.
Guide children to measure parts of their bodies with paper clips.
Discuss the resulting measurements.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is the most important person in the story big or small?
Which spoon is bigger? Which bowl is smaller?
What can you measure? How big is it?
What can you write about that is really big?
Make a really large animal.
What letter sound do you hear at the beginning of measure?
Make a tall tower. How many blocks tall is it?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: How Big Is an Elephant?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the mind builder think symbolically and introduce vocabulary (make).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to How Big Is an Elephant?
Read closely to think symbolically about the text and about numbers.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time; Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long”; Measure, describe, and compare capacity or how much can be placed inside an object using like units and words like “empty” and “full.”

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to use smaller Pattern Blocks to build the shapes of larger pattern blocks.
Have children identify the names of the shapes among the Pattern Blocks.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is there anything in your book that could be measured?
How can you pretend to be really big? How can you pretend to be really small?
What can you make with the Pattern Blocks?
What can you write that has numbers in it?
What can you make with different shapes in it? What shapes did you use?
Use the letters to make the word big.
What shape can you build out of blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Big Is an Elephant? by Rossana Bossù. Copyright © 2015 by Camelozampa. large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: How Big Is an Elephant?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to practice measuring, discuss size, and introduce vocabulary (smaller than, bigger than).
Begin Story Time by revisiting How Big Is an Elephant? and asking, How can we compare the sizes of animals?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review measurement.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time; Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long”; Use formal or informal measurement tools (e.g., balance scale, cups, blocks, paper clips, etc.) to observe and describe weight, length, and volume.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Collect, organize, and present data graphically.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Create a chart to mark each child’s height.
Measure the height of each child using the chart and discuss sizes.
Use the chart to discuss relative sizes.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is something in your book that is small? What is big?
What very small animal can you pretend to be?
How can you tell which tool is smaller?
Write about a time when you were smaller than you are now.
Can you draw two animals and make one smaller? How can you show that one is smaller?
Trace the letter S in the sand. It is the first letter in small.
How can you make what you are building bigger? How can you make it smaller?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Big Is an Elephant? by Rossana Bossù. Copyright © 2015 by Camelozampa. Translation copyright © 2018 by Annick Press Ltd. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Camelozampa S.N.C. Photo © Nenov Brothers Images/Shutterstock.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: I Can Measure

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: How Big Is an Elephant?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to think about measurements, compare classroom items, and introduce vocabulary (heavy, light).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts I Can Measure and How Big Is an Elephant?
Read closely to connect to this week’s guiding question, How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time; Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long”; Use formal or informal measurement tools (e.g., balance scale, cups, blocks, paper clips, etc.) to observe and describe weight, length, and volume; Measure, describe, and compare capacity or how much can be placed inside an object using like units and words like “empty” and “full”; Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.”

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Explore with children what happens when you pour water from one cup to another.
Compare the relative weights of the cups and discuss what changes as they go from empty to full.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Does the character measure anything in this story? What?
Which doll is bigger? Are you bigger or smaller than the dolls?
How can you tell which tool is smaller?
Can you write about something that is very heavy and hard to pick up?
Make an animal using shapes.
Which is longer, your first or last name? How can you tell?
Can you use blocks to make an animal? Is it big or small?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Big Is an Elephant? by Rossana Bossù. Copyright © 2015 by Camelozampa. Translation copyright © 2018 by Annick Press Ltd. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Camelozampa S.N.C. Photo © New Africa/Shutterstock.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: cup (M. Unal Ozmen), scale (Victor Moussa).

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: How Big Is an Elephant?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to use blocks, engage children with song, and revisit vocabulary (heavy, light).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book How Big Is an Elephant? and asking, What is something I can measure?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time; Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long”; Use formal or informal measurement tools (e.g., balance scale, cups, blocks, paper clips, etc.) to observe and describe weight, length, and volume.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Collect, organize, and present data graphically.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What is bigger than an elephant? What is smaller than you?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is anything in your book bigger than an elephant? What?
Pretend you are an elephant. What can you do?
How many scoops of rice can this container hold?
What is your favorite animal? Tell about it. Is it bigger than an elephant?
Make an animal mask.
Separate the letters into tall letters and short letters.
Make a long train and a short train. How are they alike? How are they different?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Recognize how much can be placed within an object.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Recognize how much can be placed within an object.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Recognize how much can be placed within an object.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Collect data and organize it in a graphic representation.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Recognize how much can be placed within an object.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Recognize how much can be placed within an object.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Collect data and organize it in a graphic representation.
